title: StatQuest: Random Forests in R
text: You don't need a ukulele to do statistics, but it makes it more fun.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests in R
text: Hello, I'm Josh Starmer and welcome to Stack Quest.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests in R
text: Today we're going to talk about how to build, use and evaluate random forests in R.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests in R
text: This stack quest builds on two stack quests that I've already created that demonstrate the theory behind random forests.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests in R
text: So if you're not familiar with it, check them out.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests in R
text: Just so you know, you can download all the code that I described in this tutorial using the link in the description below.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests in R
text: The first thing we do is load in GGplot 2 so we can draw fancy graphs.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests in R
text: And when I do that, our prints out a little message, it's no big deal.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests in R
text: Then we load CalPlot which just improves some of GGplot 2's default settings.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests in R
text: It overrides the GG save function and that's fine with me, so no worries here.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests in R
text: The last library we need to load is random forest.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests in R
text: So we can make random forests.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests in R
text: It also prints out some stuff in red, but it's no big deal we can move on from here.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests in R
text: For this example, we're going to get a real data set from the UCI machine learning repository.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests in R
text: Specifically, we want the heart disease data set.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests in R
text: So we make a variable called URL and set it to the location of the data we want for our random forest.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests in R
text: And this is how we read the data set into R from the URL.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests in R
text: The head function shows us the first six rows of data.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests in R
text: Unfortunately, none of the columns are labeled.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests in R
text: Wow, wow.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests in R
text: So we name the columns after the names that were listed on the UCI website.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests in R
text: The UCI website actually lists a whole lot of information about this data.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests in R
text: So it's worth checking out if you haven't done that already.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests in R
text: Hey.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests in R
text: Now when we look at the first six rows with the head function, things look a lot better.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests in R
text: However, the stir function, which describes the structure of the data, tells us that some of the columns are messed up.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests in R
text: Sex is supposed to be a factor where zero represents female and one represents male.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests in R
text: CP, aka chest pain, is also supposed to be a factor where levels one through three represent different types of pain and four represents no chest pain.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests in R
text: CA and thaw are correctly called factors, but one of the levels is question mark when we need it to be an NA.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests in R
text: So we've got some cleaning up to do.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests in R
text: The first thing we do is change the question marks to NA's.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests in R
text: Then, just to make the data easier on the eyes, we convert the zeros in sex to F for female.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests in R
text: And the ones to M for male.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests in R
text: Lastly, we convert the column into a factor.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests in R
text: Then we convert a bunch of other columns into factors since that's what they're supposed to be.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests in R
text: See the UCI website or the sample code on the stat quest blog for more details.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests in R
text: Since the CA column originally had a question mark in it, rather than NA, our thinks it's a column of strings.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests in R
text: We correct that assumption by telling our it's a column of integers.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests in R
text: And then we convert it to a factor.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests in R
text: Then we do the exact same thing for thaw.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests in R
text: The last thing we need to do to the data is make HD aka heart disease, a factor that is easy on the eyes.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests in R
text: Here I'm using a fancy trick with if else to convert the zeros to healthy and the ones to unhealthy.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests in R
text: We could have done a similar trick for sex, but I wanted to show you both ways to convert numbers towards.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests in R
text: Once we're done fixing up the data, we can check that we've made the appropriate changes with the stir function.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests in R
text: Sex is now a factor with levels F and M.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests in R
text: And everything else looks good too.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests in R
text: Hey, we're done with the boring part. Now we can have some fun.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests in R
text: Since we're going to be randomly sampling things, let's set the seed for the random number generator so that we can reproduce our results.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests in R
text: Now we impute values for the NA's and the data set with RF impute.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests in R
text: The first argument to RF impute is HD tilde dot.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests in R
text: And that means we want the HD aka heart disease column to be predicted by the data in all of the other columns.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests in R
text: Here's where we specify which data set to use. In this case, there's only one data set and it's called data.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests in R
text: Here's where we specify how many random forests RF impute should build to estimate the missing values.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests in R
text: In theory, 4 to 6 iterations is enough.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests in R
text: Just for fun, I set this parameter, itter equal to 20, but it didn't improve the estimates.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests in R
text: Lastly, we save the results. The data set with imputed values instead of NA's as data dot imputed.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests in R
text: After each iteration, RF impute prints out the out of bag, OOB, error rate.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests in R
text: This should get smaller if the estimates are improving. Since it doesn't, we can conclude that our estimates are as good as they're going to get with this method.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests in R
text: Here's where we actually build a proper random forest using the random forest function.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests in R
text: Just like when we imputed values for the NA's, we want to predict HD aka heart disease using all of the other columns in the data set.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests in R
text: However, this time we specify data dot imputed as the data set.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests in R
text: We also want random forest to return the proximity matrix, who will use this to cluster the samples at the end of the stat quest.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests in R
text: Lastly, we save the random forest and associated data like the proximity matrix as model.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests in R
text: To get a summary of the random forest and how well it performed, we can just type model on the command prompt and then hit enter.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests in R
text: Here's what gets printed to the screen.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests in R
text: The first thing is the original call to random forest.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests in R
text: Next, we see that the random forest was built to classify samples.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests in R
text: If we had used the random forest to predict weight or height, it would say regression.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests in R
text: And if we had omitted the thing, the random forest was supposed to predict entirely, it would say unsupervised.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests in R
text: Then it tells us how many trees are in the random forest. The default value is 500.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests in R
text: Later, we will check to see if 500 trees is enough for optimal classification.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests in R
text: Then it tells us how many variables or columns of data were considered at each internal node.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests in R
text: Classification trees have a default setting of the square root of the number of variables.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests in R
text: Regression trees have a default setting of the number of variables divided by 3.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests in R
text: Since we don't know if 3 is the best value, we'll fiddle with this parameter later on.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests in R
text: Here's the out of bag, OOB, error estimate.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests in R
text: This means that 83.5% of the OOB samples were correctly classified by the random forest.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests in R
text: Lastly, we have a confusion matrix.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests in R
text: There were 141 healthy patients that were correctly labeled healthy.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests in R
text: Prey, there were 27 unhealthy patients that were incorrectly classified as healthy.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests in R
text: There were 23 healthy patients that were incorrectly classified on healthy.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests in R
text: Lastly, there were 112 unhealthy patients that were correctly classified on healthy.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests in R
text: Prey, to see if 500 trees is enough for optimal classification, we can plot the error rates.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests in R
text: Here, we created data frame that formats the error rate information so that GG plot 2 will be happy.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests in R
text: This is kind of complicated, so let me walk you through it.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests in R
text: For the most part, this is all based on a matrix within model called ER.rate.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests in R
text: This is what the ER.rate matrix looks like.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests in R
text: There's one column for the out of bag error rate.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests in R
text: One column for the healthy error rate, i.e. how frequently healthy patients are misclassified.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests in R
text: Each row reflects the error rates at different stages of creating the random forest.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests in R
text: The first row contains the error rates after making the first tree.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests in R
text: The second row contains the error rates after making the first two trees.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests in R
text: The last row contains the error rates after making all 500 trees.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests in R
text: So what we're doing here is making a data frame that looks like this.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests in R
text: There's one column for the number of trees.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests in R
text: There's one column for the type of error.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests in R
text: And one column for the actual error value.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests in R
text: And here's the call to GG plot.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests in R
text: Bam.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests in R
text: The blue line shows the error rate when classifying unhealthy patients.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests in R
text: The green line shows the overall out of bag error rate.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests in R
text: The red line shows the error rate when classifying healthy patients.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests in R
text: In general, we see the error rates decrease when our random forest has more trees.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests in R
text: If we added more trees with the error rate go down further.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests in R
text: To test this hypothesis, we make a random forest with 1000 trees.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests in R
text: The out of bag error rate is the same as before.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests in R
text: And the confusion matrix shows that we didn't do a better job classifying patients.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests in R
text: And we can plot the error rates just like before.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests in R
text: Double bam.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests in R
text: And we see that the error rates stabilize right after 500 trees.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests in R
text: So adding more trees didn't help, but we would not have known this unless we used more trees.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests in R
text: Now we need to make sure we are considering the optimal number of variables at each internal node in the tree.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests in R
text: We start by making an empty vector that can hold 10 values.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests in R
text: And then we create a loop that tests different numbers of variables at each step.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests in R
text: Each time we go through the loop, I increase by 1.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests in R
text: It starts at 1 and ends after 10.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests in R
text: In this line, we are building a random forest using I to determine the number of variables to try at each step.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests in R
text: Specifically, we are setting Mtri equals I and I equals values between 1 and 10.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests in R
text: This is where we store the out of bag error rate after we build each random forest that uses a different value for Mtri.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests in R
text: This is a bit of complex code.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests in R
text: Here's what's going on.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests in R
text: Temp.model contains a matrix called Er.rate, just like model did before.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests in R
text: And we want to access the value in the last row and in the first column.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests in R
text: Ie, the out of bag error rate when all 1000 trees have been made.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests in R
text: Now we can print out the out of bag error rates for different values for Mtri.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests in R
text: The third value corresponding to Mtri equals 3, which is the default in this case, has the lowest out of bag error rate.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests in R
text: So the default value was optimal, but we wouldn't have known that unless we tried other values.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests in R
text: Lastly, we want to use the random forest to draw an Mds plot with samples.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests in R
text: This will show us how they are related to each other.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests in R
text: If you don't know what an Mds plot is, don't freak out, just check out the stack quest on.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests in R
text: We start by using the dist function to make a distance matrix from 1 minus the proximity matrix.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests in R
text: Then we run CMD scale on the distance matrix.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests in R
text: CMD scale stands for classical multi-dimensional scaling.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests in R
text: Then we calculate the percentage of variation in the distance matrix that the X and Y axes account for.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests in R
text: Again, see the other stack quest for details.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests in R
text: Then we format the data for Gg plot.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests in R
text: And then we draw the graph with Gg plot.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests in R
text: Triple BAM.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests in R
text: Unhealthy samples are on the left side.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests in R
text: Healthy samples are on the right side.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests in R
text: I wonder if patient 253 was misdiagnosed, and actually has heart disease.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests in R
text: Note, the X axis accounts for 47% of the variation in the distance matrix.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests in R
text: The Y axis only accounts for 14% of the variation in the distance matrix.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests in R
text: That means that the big differences are along the X axis.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests in R
text: Lastly, if we got a new patient and didn't know if they had heart disease and they clustered down here,

title: StatQuest: Random Forests in R
text: we'd be pretty confident that they had heart disease.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests in R
text: Her A, we've made it to the end of another exciting stack quest.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests in R
text: If you like this stack quest and want to see more of them, please subscribe.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests in R
text: And if you have any suggestions for future stack quests, well, put them in the comments below.

title: StatQuest: Random Forests in R
text: Until next time, quest on.
